Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Online Management, Experimentation, and GAme (OMEGA) of Large-Scale Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
As critical applications are converging onto the Internet, effective response to large-scale network dynamics like failures and demand spikes is gaining more importance. Major portion of the time for handling such network dynamics is determining how to respond, mostly performed manually in the current practice. Experienced human administrators are typically the ones who can quickly find a close-to-optimum response. However, as the networks are getting larger and more diverse, managing and attaining effective responses for an online operational network necessitates meta-tools to swiftly learn and characterize the network.

This project will develop tools for automated management of a running network by framing heuristic optimization, empirical learning, experimental design, and network management with a simulation interface. The project will develop an online management and experimentation system for large-scale networks in an environment that enables trainee administrators to explore what-if scenarios, without having to risk the network operation. The project will also develop algorithms for empirical characterization of network dynamics, and tools for quick and close-to-optimal configuration of numerous network parameters in response to failures or customer traffic trends.

The project will integrate behavioral scientific concepts into the practice of operational network management. The automated management using online optimization may establish a foundation for managing multi-owner systems, e.g., power grid, transportation, and water infrastructure networks. The project's heuristic optimization and experiment design methods as well as the approach to operator training are applicable to training in safety and mission critical industries where mistakes of ill-trained administrators are intolerable, e.g., airline pilot and nuclear reactor administrator training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has explored and made contributions on several topics in network management research including (i) meta-networking tools for automated management of a running network, (ii) a game environment, Network Management Game (NGM), that enables trainee network administrators to explore what-if scenarios without having to risk the network operation, (iii) parallel routing techniques for load-balancing of network traffic using multi-core routers, (iv) trajectory-based routing protocols for end-to-end traffic engineering in multi-hop wireless networks, (v) probabilistic heuristic optimization algorithms to search for the best response to dynamics in a running network, and (vi) Cloud-Assisted Routing (CAR) designs for increased network robustness and cost-efficiency.

The project revealed several interesting findings, some of which are;

(1) Using NGM, we observed 21% average performance improvement in trainee administrators’ management skills for an interior gateway protocol (IGP) routing configuration problem in a network without failures. We further focused on two basic skills needed by network administrators: Discovering and selecting paths with high bandwidth, and decoupling flows to better load balance the network traffic. For our test group, we observed 13% to 21% skill improvement, which supports the success of NMG, particularly when the players are forced to master each stage of the game.

(2) The project resulted in a multi-path routing framework, Multi-Core Parallel Routing (MCPR), that explicitly considers multi-core routers in design while utilizing the highly optimized legacy shortest-path calculations. MCPR leverages the advent of multi-core CPUs in routers and eases the computational complexities of legacy multi-path routing algorithms by dividing the overall multipath routing problem into smaller parts and lending each part to one separate CPU core.

(3) For network management and configuration, the project yielded a hybrid black-box optimization framework, Probabilistic Trans-Algorithmic Search (PTAS), which applies a search algorithm to determine how to best distribute available time budget among multiple optimization search algorithms. Using a “roulette wheel” approach, PTAS probabilistically favors more successful algorithms and “transfers” the best result(s) among the individual algorithms. PTAS systematizes how to “search for the best search” and hybridize a set of search algorithms to attain a better search. Our experiments showed that PTAS framework can be successfully applied to automated network management problems such as IGP routing and wireless transmitter configurations.

The project aimed to integrate behavioral scientific concepts into the practice of operational network management. The game framework for network administrator training was presented at the 64th North American Network Operator Group (NANOG) meeting. The automated management using online optimization may establish a foundation for managing multi-owner systems, e.g., power grid, transportation, and water infrastructure networks. Some of the concepts, such as architectures for information sharing, developed from the project were considered for critical infrastructures systems such as power grid. The project’s heuristic optimization and experiment design methods as well as the approach to operator training are applicable to training in safety and mission critical industries where mistakes of ill-trained administrators are intolerable, e.g., airline pilot and nuclear reactor administrator training.

The project supported several graduate and undergraduate students and contributed to the development of a STEM workforce, which is highly needed for the nation. A total of five (5) Ph.D. students graduated or progressed towards their degrees and two (2) undergraduate students found opportunity to perform cutting-edge research in the project. The project also resulted in five (5) journal and eight (8) conference publications at venues with high impact to the network management research communities. Further, one (1) patent on cloud-assisted routing technology was awarded from the efforts.
